It is good to know that under President Obama, DHS is protecting the private data of DACA enrollees.  Unfortunately, the Obama Administration ends on January 20.  That is why we asked President Obama to take action that would protect DACA recipients and prevent the new administration from using the recipients’ personal information for purposes not originally intended, such as deportation.  Given the statements of the incoming Trump Administration, DACA enrollees are currently living in fear of an uncertain future.  They fear being ripped from their home, their family, and the only country they know.  My colleagues and I urge President Obama to take immediate action to protect these young immigrants and enable them to continue contributing their talents to America, their only home.

Glad that President Obama came to Capitol Hill today to urge Democrats to protect and defend the #AffordableCareAct.  I am proud to have voted for the #ACA, which has made health coverage affordable for millions of Americans (including many in our 40th District) and reduced America's uninsured rate to an all-time low.  If congressional leaders and the Trump Administration try to dismantle this lifesaving law, I'll fight them every step of the way to protect health coverage for the American people.  #ACAWorks

Thrilled that the House has passed H.R. 315, the Improving Access to Maternity Care Act, which I introduced with Congressman Burgess and Congresswoman Eshoo!  I helped lead this legislation because I want every mother and baby to have access to excellent maternity care.  As co-chair of the Congressional Maternity Care Caucus, I know that babies are born healthier when their mothers receive comprehensive prenatal and childbirth care.  Our bill will help the Department of Health and Human Services identify which areas of the U.S. are in need of maternity care professionals, so that the Department can place doctors and midwives in these areas to offer comprehensive prenatal and childbirth care to mothers and babies.

40TH DISTRICT HIGH SCHOOLERS: The deadline for the 24th Annual Lucille Roybal-Allard Student Art Competition is Friday, February 3, 2017, at 5:00 PM PST!  The competition is open to all 9th-12th grade students residing in the 40th Congressional District, which includes the cities of #Bell, #BellGardens, #Commerce, #Cudahy, #Downey, #HuntingtonPark, #Maywood, #Paramount, #Vernon, and parts of #Bellflower, #EastLosAngeles, #FlorenceGraham, #SouthLosAngeles, and #WalnutPark.  The winning student will be awarded a trip to attend the opening of the national exhibit in Washington, DC, where his or her artwork will be put on display in the U.S. Capitol for one year.  The student will also receive a $1,000 scholarship and a gift certificate for art supplies.    A submission must be an original concept.  It cannot be a reproduction, nor inspired by an existing photo, painting, graphic, advertisement or any work by another person, nor infringe upon the rights of a third party.  Complete guidelines and entry forms are available by calling Kim Tachiki-Chin at (323) 721-8790.  More info is available at http://bit.ly/2jsC9Iu.

I am confident he will be an aggressive advocate for all Californians, just as he has been for his congressional constituents over the past 24 years.
With the passing of former Congressman Bob Garcia, our nation has lost a dedicated and committed leader. We will miss his strong advocacy for our Latino community and for all Americans.

Proud to join Rep. Linda Sánchez to introduce the ACCESS Act, which will reauthorize year-round Pell Grants!  Education can help many of our student constituents reach the middle class, but right now just 21 percent of America’s low-income students get their bachelor’s degrees by age 24.  Reauthorizing year-round #PellGrants will help more of these students complete their #HigherEducation and graduate faster and with less debt.

I am so excited to have Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal join me as a Co-Chair of the Congressional Women’s Working Group on Immigration Reform.  As an immigrant to America herself, a longtime civil rights activist, and the first Indian American woman in the House of Representatives, her experiences and dedication will enrich our group and our mission.  As we prepare for a Congress in which the needs of immigrant women and children will be a prominent issue, I could not be prouder to be working with Congresswoman Jayapal and every member of the Women’s Working Group to ensure these women and children are treated with compassion and care.  Today, we held the group’s 2017 kickoff meeting at my Capitol Hill office.

Today marks 75 years since the signing of Executive Order 9066, which led to the shameful internment of more than 120,000 Americans of Japanese descent.  As we reflect and remember those dark days in American history today, let us reaffirm our commitment to the timeless and uniquely American creed of liberty, justice, and equal treatment for all, regardless of who we are or where we come from.

The DHS memos on immigration reported by the Washington Post are troubling. I urge the administration to carefully consider the likely devastating effect of such orders on families, our communities, and our economy.   I will continue to fight for comprehensive immigration reform, and to stop this elevated attack on our country’s most vulnerable.

The Department of Homeland Security has released memos implementing the Administration's executive orders on immigration.  These orders will have serious negative consequences for our country, ripping apart families and crippling our economy.  As we work to reform our broken immigration system, we should be focusing on deporting those who are a threat to our country, not on those who are contributing members of our communities.  I will keep fighting against the president's anti-immigrant actions.  At the same time, I will continue advocating for comprehensive immigration reform that keeps our country safe while keeping families together, and creating a pathway to legalization and eventual citizenship.

Today, I reintroduced the Children’s Act for Responsible Employment (or CARE Act) to provide crucial protections for kids working in US agriculture.  Agriculture is the only industry in which children as young as 12 are allowed to labor with virtually no restrictions on the number of hours they work outside of the school day.  All of America’s children deserve to be protected equally under our laws, and no child should be discriminated against based on the work they do.  The time has come for the US to bring child labor laws in line with our American values.

Today marks the four-year anniversary of the Supreme Court’s Shelby County v. Holder decision, which struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act. As a result of the Court’s decision, many Americans are without crucial voting rights protections in states and counties with severe records of voter discrimination.  That is utterly wrong.  In America, the right to vote is fundamental, and must be protected from any and all attempts to weaken it. It defines our nation’s values and allows for the proper representation of all communities. We must act now to pass the Voting Rights Advancement Act, so that we can strengthen protections for Americans at the ballot box and restore the right of eligible voters to participate in our democracy.  #RestoreTheVOTE #RestoreTheVRA #VRAA

Right now, the Coast Guard doesn’t have a single heavy icebreaker in the Arctic, while Russia has 41 total Arctic-focused icebreakers (including four heavy icebreakers) that are active or under construction.  My amendment would have helped protect our sovereign Arctic interests.  Sadly, the GOP majority sank my amendment.

I am outraged at the addition of $1.6 billion of unnecessary and unwarranted border wall funding to a so-called security “minibus” spending bill.  The majority party is playing a cynical political game with our national security.  Every Democrat on the Appropriations Committee opposed the DHS Appropriations bill that included wall funding, but the GOP is now trying to force Democrats to vote for wall spending that takes funds away from our nation’s real security vulnerabilities.  It is unconscionable to tie frivolous wall funding to this minibus bill that helps protect our country and support our servicemembers.  The fact that Senate Democrats have indicated any money for a wall is a non-starter demonstrates that this purely a political play by the House GOP.  The majority shouldn't focus on devising political tricks, or on pressing for this unneeded wall spending.  The American people deserve better.  Instead, the majority should focus on making spending choices that keep the government running and truly keep our country safe.

In an effort to protect the future health of children and families, I introduced an amendment to restore funding for the Section 317 program (the backbone of our nation’s immunization infrastructure) and the CDC Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Program. Unfortunately, low-income and minority children often live in communities with less access to vaccines and more exposure to lead; my amendment offered funding to combat these disparities. Sadly, the GOP opposed my amendment. The health of children should not be a partisan issue!

Introduced an amendment to restore funding to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ).  #AHRQ produces the evidence, tools, and training needed to change what’s wrong and share what’s right in day-to-day health care delivery.  While the National Institutes of Health’s discoveries of cures and lifesaving treatments are critical to patients, AHRQ’s work shows us the best way to deliver those cures and treatments!  Unfortunately, the majority opposed my amendment to protect AHRQ.

Introduced an amendment to restore funding for Titles VII and VIII, which are the only federally funded programs to improve the healthcare workforce’s size, distribution, and diversity. My amendment would have supported the education of a more diverse group of healthcare professionals, including primary care doctors, nurses, behavioral health providers, public health professionals, and geriatric specialists. It doesn’t make sense to cut and consolidate these programs at a time when healthcare demand is on the rise! Unfortunately, the majority opposed my amendment.

No survivor of sexual violence should be forced to choose between dropping out of school, and having to attend classes with or live down the hall from their assaulter!  That is why I introduced an amendment today to ensure Title IX adequately addresses sexual harassment and violence.  For too long, Title IX was not properly enforced. My amendment would have ensured that sexual violence investigations on campuses would be fair, impartial, and equitable; interim measures and accommodations would be available for complainants; and survivors would be protected from further barriers to their educations. I’m disappointed that the GOP voted against this amendment.

The president’s action to end DACA in six months is outrageous. This is a heartbreaking day for our country, and for the bright young DACA recipients who know no home but America.  Our country needs these young people and their talents more than ever to strengthen our economy and our society.  President Trump’s decision to end DACA is cruel, destructive, and un-American.  The United States is a nation built in large part by the contributions, innovations, and inventions of immigrants. The president’s action against DACA only weakens the United States. And it is why I have helped introduce the American Hope Act of 2017, which creates a path to permanent legal status and eventual citizenship for DACA recipients and all qualifying DREAMers brought to the US as children.  I call on my fellow congressmembers to join me in supporting these bills, so that we may help these American youth continue to strengthen our country.  #DefendDACA #DACA #DREAMers #DREAMAct

The Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Community Health Centers (CHCs) bill brought to the floor by Republicans today was unacceptable.  This bill cuts $6.35 billion over eight years from the Prevention and Public Health Fund. These cuts will decimate community programs that help keep people healthy and avoid expensive medical treatments. The bill also penalizes those who miss a private health insurance premium payment by shortening the current grace period of 90 days to 30 days.  This shortened time will lead to as many as 688,000 low and moderate income Americans losing their state Marketplace health insurance coverage. In addition, while the bill provides some relief for our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands as they struggle to recover from the devastation of Hurricane Maria, the bill is inadequate to help these hurricane victims. I strongly support the reauthorization of CHIP and CHCs, but not if it means including the bill’s deeply damaging provisions, which will cause great harm to working families.

On behalf of America’s future generations who will be saddled with an unsurmountable debt created by H.R. 1, the Republican tax plan, I strongly opposed this bill.  This rushed piece of legislation will not only add more than $1.7 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years, but it will also shift the burden of paying for that debt to our hardworking families.  Despite our Republican colleagues' assertions that this tax plan will benefit the majority of Americans, numerous economists disagree.  They note that nearly 45% of all households with children will see a tax increase, while 80% of our wealthiest citizens will receive a tax cut by 2027.  Even more egregious, this tax bill seeks to eliminate the long-standing state and local tax deduction, subjecting every wage earner's income to double taxation.  This defeats the original framers' intent to avoid a system of double taxation.  The original tax code, drafted in 1913, consisted of three pages in its entirety and included the state and local tax deduction at the core of its responsible tax policy to ensure state and local governments could raise revenues for public schools, police, fire, and emergency services.  Plain and simple, this tax plan is a tremendous windfall for our wealthiest 1% and large corporations.  It favors large businesses over small businesses, it favors sending jobs overseas rather than creating jobs at home, it favors the wealthy over hourly wage earners, and it pays for these tax cuts for the wealthy by raising taxes on our middle class families to the detriment of Medicare, Medicaid, education, and other vital public services.  The fact is, this bill is so skewed to benefit the wealthiest 1% in America that it could more accurately be named "H.R. 1%."  In the name of the other 99% of Americans, I voted against H.R. 1.

As a strong #NetNeutrality supporter, I am deeply disappointed by the Federal Communications Commission’s vote to repeal the rules protecting net neutrality.  Their vote jeopardizes Americans’ free speech and our nation’s thriving internet economy.  Without net neutrality, ISPs – internet service providers – will be able to restrict the online content my constituents can access, degrade their internet viewing experience, and raise the cost of accessing certain websites and online services.  ISPs will also get to charge websites and application makers higher prices to join ‘fast lanes’ for online traffic.  Ending net neutrality will be a boon to the wealthy who can afford faster speeds and greater access.  But working people will be burdened with a slower internet.  Entrepreneurs and innovators who can’t afford to compete on a pay-to-play internet will be unable to spread their great ideas and create jobs out of those ideas.  Activists will lose their access to a neutral internet, and with it, a powerful advocacy tool.  Today’s #FCC vote makes it all the more important to fight for strong net neutrality rules that protect consumers and keep the internet strong – and that is exactly what I plan to do.
